segments.text: Do you think you'll enjoy village life?
It will be very quiet after life in the city, even Manchester.
I'm sure I'll find something to keep me busy.
You might like the hospital.
What sort of hospital is it? How many beds?
Well, it's barely a hospital.
Don't let Dr. Clarkson hear you-he thinks it's second only to St. Thomas's.
It's a cottage hospital, of course, but quite well equipped.
Who pays for it?
Oh, good let's talk about money.
My father gave the building and an endowment to run it.
In a way, he set up his own memorial.
But how splendid! And Mr. Lloyd George's new insurance measures will help.
Please don't speak that man's name-we are about to eat.
I will hold it steady, and you can help yourself.
Yes, I know. Thank you.
You'll soon get used to the way things are done here.
If you mean that I'm accustomed to a very different life from this, then that is true.
What will you do with your time?
I've got a job in Ripon. I said I'd start tomorrow.
A job? In a partnership
You might have heard of it-Harl and Carter.
They need someone who understands industrial law, I'm glad to say
although I'm afraid most of it will be wills and conveyancing.
You do know I mean to involve you in the running of the estate?
Don't worry, there are plenty of hours in the day, and of course, I'll have the weekend.
We'll discuss it later. We mustn't bore the ladies.
But what is a weekend?
